<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_read_:
```c
static int lfs_dir_read_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir, struct lfs_info *info) {
    memset(info, 0, sizeof(*info));

    // special offset for '.' and '..'
    if (dir->pos == 0) {
        info->type = LFS_TYPE_DIR;
        strcpy(info->name, ".");
        dir->pos += 1;
        return true;
    } else if (dir->pos == 1) {
        info->type = LFS_TYPE_DIR;
        strcpy(info->name, "..");
        dir->pos += 1;
        return true;
    }

    while (true) {
        if (dir->id == dir->m.count) {
            if (!dir->m.split) {
                return false;
            }

            int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir->m, dir->m.tail);
            if (err) {
                return err;
            }

            dir->id = 0;
        }

        int err = lfs_dir_getinfo(lfs, &dir->m, dir->id, info);
        if (err && err != LFS_ERR_NOENT) {
            return err;
        }

        dir->id += 1;
        if (err != LFS_ERR_NOENT) {
            break;
        }
    }

    dir->pos += 1;
    return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
strcpy(info->name, ".");
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: strcpy(info->name, ".") copies two bytes ('.' and '\0') into info->name. The snippet does not show the definition or guaranteed size of info->name, so if info->name has length < 2 (e.g. 0 or 1), this will write beyond the bounds of the destination and violate Rule 21.17. Unless it is provable from the surrounding code that info->name is sized >= 2, this use is a potential out‑of‑bounds access.
